verses.text: These also are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied.
verses.comment: This opening credits the collection of proverbs to Solomon and notes their preservation under Hezekiah, emphasizing how being faithful to tradition preserved the wisdom for future generations (see 2 Kings 18:1-5).

verses.text: It is the glory of God to conceal a matter, but the honor of kings is to search out a matter.
verses.comment: God's wisdom is unfathomable (Romans 11:33), yet rulers are called to pursue knowledge; this sets a pattern for both divine mystery and established authority searching for truth.

verses.text: As the heavens for height, and the earth for depth, so the heart of kings is unsearchable.
verses.comment: Just as God’s mind is beyond full comprehension, those given authority bear a similar complexity, requiring discernment and respect (Daniel 2:21).

verses.text: Remove the dross from the silver, and a vessel comes forth for the silversmith.
verses.comment: A call to purification echoes later teaching about sanctification (John 15:2); the imagery suggests that true value is found after refining—a process often associated with spiritual growth.

verses.text: Remove the wicked from the king’s presence, and his throne will be established in righteousness.
verses.comment: The stability of righteous authority depends on removing evil influences, foreshadowing Christ as the truly righteous King (Hebrews 1:8).

verses.text: Do not exalt yourself in the king’s presence, and do not stand in the place of great men.
verses.comment: Humility is encouraged, anticipating Christ’s teaching to take the lower place at banquets (see Luke 14:10). Spiritual growth is linked with humility before recognized authority.

verses.text: For it is better that you be told, 'Come up here,' than that you should be put lower in the presence of the prince whom your eyes have seen.
verses.comment: Teaching self-effacement, this verse was echoed by Jesus; dignity is gained by proper order, not self-promotion.

verses.text: Do not hastily bring a matter to court; for what will you do in the end, when your neighbor puts you to shame?
verses.comment: Caution in disputes is urged; Christ similarly taught reconciliation and prudence before appealing to judgment (Matthew 5:25).

verses.text: Argue your case with your neighbor himself, and do not reveal another’s secret.
verses.comment: Direct address in conflict; privacy and honor are affirmed, paralleling Jesus’ teaching on confronting a brother privately before involving others.

verses.text: Lest he who hears it expose your shame, and your bad reputation will not be taken away.
verses.comment: Gossip and indiscretion bring lasting harm; Christian tradition holds the tongue's discipline as vital for holiness (James 3:2-12).

verses.text: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in settings of silver.
verses.comment: True wisdom is precious and beautiful; recall Christ’s words as pearls of value (Matthew 13:45-46), highlighting the sacramental role of speech.

verses.text: Like an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold is a wise rebuke to a listening ear.
verses.comment: Correction is a treasure to those receptive, echoing the importance of listening to authoritative reproof for spiritual growth.

verses.text: Like the cold of snow in time of harvest is a faithful messenger to those who send him; he refreshes the soul of his masters.
verses.comment: Faithful service brings refreshing joy—a theme fulfilled in the apostles as trusted messengers of the gospel (1 Corinthians 4:1).

verses.text: Whoever boasts of giving gifts he does not give is like clouds and wind without rain.
verses.comment: Empty promises are condemned; spiritual discipline requires both intention and action (see James 2:17).

verses.text: By patience a ruler can be persuaded, and a soft tongue can break a bone.
verses.comment: Gentleness and perseverance achieve success where force fails; patience is a key virtue (Galatians 5:22).

verses.text: If you find honey, eat only what you need, lest you have too much and vomit it.
verses.comment: This wisdom highlights moderation—too much of even a good thing can cause harm, an ancient lesson in temperance.

verses.text: Let your foot seldom be in your neighbor’s house, lest he grow weary of you and hate you.
verses.comment: Respect for boundaries and consideration for others is a mark of genuine love and community.

verses.text: A man who gives false testimony against his neighbor is like a club, a sword, and a sharp arrow.
verses.comment: Bearing false witness is a grave harm and breaks the commandment, paralleling the church’s injunctions against calumny and falsehood.

verses.text: Trusting in an unreliable person in times of trouble is like a broken tooth or a foot out of joint.
verses.comment: Reliability is crucial in fellowship, reflecting the high value placed on faithfulness among Christ’s followers (1 Corinthians 4:2).

verses.text: Whoever sings songs to a heavy heart is like vinegar poured on soda.
verses.comment: Insensitive cheer can worsen sorrow; true empathy is essential, anticipating St. Paul’s teaching to mourn with those who mourn (Romans 12:15).

verses.text: If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
verses.comment: Mercy toward enemies foreshadows Christ’s command to love your enemies, demonstrating supernatural charity and forgiveness.

verses.text: For you will heap burning coals on his head, and the LORD will reward you.
verses.comment: Repaying evil with good brings justice and grace; the idea of God rewarding hidden virtue is central to Christian spirituality.

verses.text: The north wind brings forth rain; so does a backbiting tongue cause an angry face.
verses.comment: Just as natural forces have predictable effects, so does gossip; discipline of speech is again stressed.

verses.text: It is better to dwell in the corner of a housetop than in a house with a quarrelsome wife.
verses.comment: Peace at home is prized above comfort; spiritual harmony in relationships is foundational for household unity.

verses.text: Like cold water to a weary soul is good news from a distant land.
verses.comment: The joy of good tidings foreshadows gospel proclamation; news of salvation refreshes those who are spiritually weary.

verses.text: Like a muddied spring or a polluted fountain is a righteous person who gives way before the wicked.
verses.comment: Compromising righteousness leads to corruption, a warning to persevere in goodness and stand firm against evil.

verses.text: It is not good to eat too much honey, nor to seek one’s own glory.
verses.comment: Moderation in indulgence and humility before ambition are long-held virtues for saints and the faithful.

verses.text: A person who lacks self-control is like a city broken into and left without walls.
verses.comment: Self-control safeguards against spiritual peril; it is foundational for Christian maturity, and is also a fruit of the Spirit.
